case_vignette:
A 66-year-old female with past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation presents with a slowly growing mass on the right breast. She states the spot initially began as a small bruise then progressively enlargened over the past few months and now spontaneously bleeds. Examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. An excisional biopsy reveals atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.  The patient is diagnosed with angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of cancer that originates from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

I have a slowly growing mass on my right breast that started as a small bruise and now it spontaneously bleeds.

It has been enlarging over the past few months.

Final Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of the breast (radiation-induced)
